Us old folks were raised in the period of till death do us part. Which people aren't buying anymore. You get to a point where you may have less than 20 years left to live and it becomes obvious to those that are in unhappy marriages that this is their last chance to enjoy what little time the have left. Maybe, even live a little longer.

I find this quite hard to believe. My work is exclusively divorce, complicated divorces, for over 20 years. Rather than seeing a decline in my work there has been an increase.  It used to be that this time of year would see the "slow down" where parties would "wait" to after the holidays..now, for many years, at least 5, the Holiday season is the same madness as the rest of the year.  The ages of the parties are older....ofter over 60.  As to Europe, it is well known the institution of marriage is practically non-exist there...so of course, a low divorce rate.

MAYBE . . .

...because there are many variables involved. Firstly, a general physician must be a good, caring and sensitive listener. But, if the doctor genuinely cares about the patient -- the patients and doctor must share the same interests, cultural and personal values.

Studies have demonstrated that in any psychotherapeutic relationship, the best prognosis is attained when both have similar interests -- even if they are not known and determined retrospectively.

So, too with a general physician and his/her patient. Frankly, I don't know if someone with psychological or existential problems or concerns is better served by talking with a good friend, a physician or a so-called "therapist."

Of course any medical doctor can prescribe any drugs. But here is a significant warning: psychotropic medications are a specialty that should not be given by a generalist. Yet, the majority of prescriptions for say, Prozac and Valium, and... are written by internists or GPs.

Also, the type of intimacy which occurs with "a secret therapist" may be disruptive in the general medical interaction.

Wrong! Drugs given for psychiatric or psychological conditions should be prescribed by an experienced psychopharmacologist.

Certain not via (what you refer to as) "the secret therapist."

You're right Ellen and in addition to all those great cultural venues. You can also visit the Weir Farm National Historic Site was home to three generations of American artists. Julian Alden Weir, a leading figure in American art and the development of American Impressionism, acquired the farm in 1882. After Weir, the artistic legacy was continued by his daughter, painter Dorothy Weir Young and her husband, sculptor Mahonri Young, followed by New England painters Sperry and Doris Andrews. Today, the 60-acre park, which includes the Weir House, Weir and Young Studios, barns, gardens, and Weir Pond, is one of the nation's finest remaining landscapes of American art.

Mr. Sendak's property is, in fact, where "the Wild Things Are".    The northern part of our town is wooded, hilly and beautiful, and his estate will be a perfect place for his museum.  Ridgefield is most definitely not in the middle of nowhere.  While visiting the Sendak Museum, people could also visit the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, see a live show at the Ridgefield Playhouse, see a movie at The Prospector Theater, attend a performance of the Ridgefield Symphony Orchestra, learn about our 300+ year history at the Keeler Tavern Museum (once home to Cass Gilbert) or the Ridgefield Historical Society, and dine in any one of our many wonderful restaurants.  All are welcome!

China has a host of it's own problems from it's accelerated economic growth. It is not a good example to cite or follow.

Why even compare the two countries? The only thing they have in common is a population of over a billion. Unlike China, India has yet to lift over 600 million people out of abject poverty. This isn't something to gloss over. Visit Shanghai, Beijing, Mumbai and Delhi, it is clear that India has so much catching up to do economically. Until that happens, I can't see India prioritizing green issues.
